name: p-chlorocinnamic acid
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.

name: p-chlorocinnamic acid
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.
Reason: The compound p-chlorocinnamic acid is based on the cinnamic acid structure. Basic phenylpropanoic acids have a melting point around 133 °C. The presence of a conjugated double bond typically increases the melting point due to increased rigidity and planarity in the molecule, which could add up to 50 °C. The chloro substituent adds electronegativity and dipole interactions, which usually increases melting point as well; this could add approximately 40 °C because of the strong -I inductive effect and possible intermolecular interactions. The carboxylic acid group strongly contributes to melting point due to hydrogen bonding and the potential for dimer formation, this might add another 25 °C. Combining these effects predictively:
